Question: Interactive Antlr: :I'm trying to write a simple interactive (using System.in as source) language using antlr, and I have a few problems with it. The examples I've found on the web are all using a per line cycle, e.g.:while(readline)  result = parse(line)  doStuff(result)But what if I'm writing something like pascal/smtp/etc, with a "first line" looks like X requirment? I know it can be checked in doStuff, but I think logically it is part of the syntax.Or what if a command is split into multiple lines? I can trywhile(readline)  lines.add(line)  try    result = parse(lines)    lines = []    doStuff(result)  catch    nopBut with this I'm also hiding real errors.Or I could reparse all lines everytime, but:it will be slow there are instructions I don't want to run twiceCan this be done with ANTLR, or if not, with something else?
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer: You can use ANTLR's push mode to handle this. You can define a lexer rule that starts the line with a certain character and then switch to a different parser rule that will continue to parse until it encounters a certain character. This way, you can handle commands that span multiple lines.

```java
grammar Interactive;

parse
 : (line EOF)+
 ;

line
 : commandLine         #Command
 | expressionLine      #Expression
 ;

commandLine
 : 'X' requirement EOF  #RequirementCommand
 ;

expressionLine
 : expression EOF      #ExpressionCommand
 ;

requirement
 : ID '=' INT           #Requirement
 ;

expression
 : <assoc=right> ID '^' INT    #Exponent
 | ID                        #Variable
 ;

ID  : [a-zA-Z]+ ;
INT : [0-9]+ ;
WS  : [ \t\r\n]+ -> skip ;
```

In this grammar, `commandLine` and `expressionLine` are two different parser rules that will be activated depending on whether the line starts with 'X' or not. You can then handle the 'X' command and the expression separately.

For the interactive part, you can read lines from System.in and feed them to the parser one by one.

```java
public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        ANTLRInputStream input = new ANTLRInputStream(System.in);
        InteractiveLexer lexer = new InteractiveLexer(input);
        CommonTokenStream tokens = new CommonTokenStream(lexer);
        InteractiveParser parser = new InteractiveParser(tokens);

        while(true) {
            System.out.print("> ");
            String line = System.console().readLine();
            lexer.setInputStream(new ANTLRInputStream(line));
            InteractiveParser.ParseContext tree = parser.parse();
            // do something with tree
        }
    }
}
```

This way, you can handle commands and expressions separately and also handle errors in a more logical way.
